citation.article-title: Angulomicrobium tetraedrale, a new genus of budding bacteria with radial cell symmetry.

p.s: Description of Angulomicrobium tetraedrale sp. nov.
Angulomicrobium tetraedrale (Gr. adj. tetrahedral)
("mushroom-shaped bacterium", Whittenbury and Nicoll, 1971, p. 12, "tetrahedron," Namsaraev, Zavarzin, 1972, p. 999)
Cells are Gram-negative, single and paited (1.1 x 1.5 and for strain 1109-0.95 x 1.2 μm), non-motile.
The cells have radial symmetry, type strain has tetrahedral form of the cell, others have flat form.
Multiplication is by budding from the top of the tetrahedron or from the top of the triangle.
Mother and daughter cells are similar in form and size.
They don't have a complex membranous system.
Colonies are of white color, round, mucous with pearly shine.
Chemoorganotroph.
Carbohydrates, amino acids, organic acids, alcohols are utilized as the sole sources of carbon and energy (Table 1).
Sugars are used via Hexose-monophosphate pathway and via Entner-Doudoroff pathway.
Type strain has enzymes of Embden-Meyerhof pathway.
Organic growth factors not required, but they stimulate growth.
For certain strains (1109) it is necessary to add peptone-yeast extract.
Aerobic.
Catalase-, oxidase-positive.
Temperature range is 15-35 °C, 28-30 °C is optimal.
Optimal pH for growth is around neutrality 6.8-7.0.
Sensitivity towards antibiotics (μg/ml) for type strain (68.2 mol. % according to another determination).
Isolated from swampy soil near Moscow.
Type strain Z-2821 (AUCM B-1335), strain 1109 (AUCM B-1336)
